what: opened public schools for the first day of classes
permitted all child care centres to open, and increased capacity limit to 15 children per room

who: government of saskatchewan, chief medical health officer; work safe saskatchewan
what: announced that all non-essential employees in government of saskatchewan ministries, agencies and crown corporations will be part of a phased-in work-from-home policy. this requires any employee able to work from home to do so immediately. all non-government workers are encouraged to work from home where possible.

child care centres co-located in schools will remain operational and open spaces exclusively to workers who are associated with the pandemic responses who need child care during the covid-19 pandemic.
closure of elementary, middle and high schools; suspension of classes

who: minister of health and social services
what: announced that high school students for the region of chaudière-appalaches (mrc des etchemins, beauce-sartigan and robert-cliche) can return to school; students in secondary 3, 4 and 5 can attend school every other day in combination with online learning

who: minister of health and social services
what: announced that the regions of the metropolitan community of quebec (including lévis), the city of gatineau and the mrc des collines-de-l'outaouais will have their primary and secondary schools closed and moved to online learning

announced that for all regions of quebec, with the exception of nunavik and terres-cries-de-la-baie-james, secondary schools will reopen with reinforced measures including the distribution of 2 procedural masks per day per student and per teacher; mandated masks in class without exceptions

who: ministry of health and social services
what: closed secondary schools and mandated distance learning according to the established school calendar

who: minister of health and social services
what: announced that students may remove masks in university facilities, colleges and professional schools when a distance of 1.5 metres is maintained
announced that daycares will begin reopening on may 11 outside of montréal and on may 19 in montréal (subsequently postponed). high schools, colleges and universities will not reopen until september.
encouraged employers to be flexible, where possible, to let their employees telecommute from home

who: government of prince edward island, chief public health officer
what: resumed full-time classroom learning for k–12 with public health measures in place
began opening public schools for the first day of classes; some schools delayed opening until september 9 to stagger orientation and the first day of class
permitted all child care centres to operate at full capacity
encouraging businesses to have a plan for supporting their employees who may become ill and quarantined. also, employers should look for work-from-home options.
announced that licensed daycares would be closed for an indefinite period

who: government of ontario, chief medical officer of health
what: moved all publicly funded and private elementary and secondary schools to teacher-led remote learning

who: minister of education, chief medical officer of health
what: permitted elementary and secondary schools in 7 regions to resume in-person learning with targeted asymptomatic testing, enhanced screening and mandatory masking for students in grades 1 to 3 (grey bruce health unit, haliburton, kawartha, pine ridge district health unit, hastings and prince edward counties health unit, kingston, frontenac and lennox & addington health unit, leeds, grenville and lanark district health unit, peterborough public health, renfrew county and district health unit)
moved publicly funded and private secondary schools in the 27 public health unit regions not noted in on432 to teacher-led remote learning

opened most public schools. no limits on class sizes for k-8 students, who will attend school 5 days per week in class cohorts, with 300 minutes of instruction per day. secondary schools will open with blended model with class cohorts of approximately 15 students and in-person attendance for at least 50% of instructional days. students in k-3 are encouraged, but not required, to wear non-medical or cloth masks. students in grades 4 to 12 must wear non-medical or cloth masks indoors in school, including in hallways. some school boards may have additional requirements for students in these grades. all staff in schools must wear masks, with reasonable exceptions for medical conditions.
closures of at-risk workplaces, while encouraging businesses to explore opportunities to continue operations through work-from-home and innovative business models.
closure of all publicly funded schools in ontario for 2 weeks following march break
for iqaluit, permitted child care facilities to open

who: government of nunavut, department of education services
what: for iqaluit, all child care facilities closed

who: government of nunavut, chief public health officer
what: for iqaluit, all non-essential government employees are to work from home
permitted child care facilities in baffin, kitikmeot, chesterfield inlet, baker lake, coral harbour, naujaat, rankin inlet and whale cove to open with enhanced cleaning protocols

who: government of nunavut, department of education services
what: all child care facilities in arviat are recommended to remain closed
for arviat and whale cove, permitted daycares to open to all children, with enhanced cleaning protocols
for whale cove, reduced capacity in daycares to care for children of essential workers only
permitted business and government offices to open for in-person work for all of nunavut, except arviat
for all nunavut, except arviat, permitted daycares to open to all children, with enhanced cleaning protocols
announced transitional procedures for government employees in sanikiluaq to work from home and encouraged others to do so where possible

who: government of nunavut, chief public health officer
what: recommended closure of child care facilities in sanikiluaq due to covid-19 cases in the community

who: government of nunavut, workers’ safety and compensation commission
what: returned all government employees to working in office. the government of nunavut is the territory's largest employer. permitted other workplaces to open in-person.

who: government of nunavut, department of education services
what: opened daycares using newly developed guidelines for child care facility reopening, including information on enhanced cleaning and hygiene, and physical distancing during drop-off and pickup
announced transitional procedures for government employees to work from home and encouraged others to do so where possible
schools and daycares are closed for minimum 3 weeks.
reopened all schools in yellowknife, ndilǫ̨, dettah and behchokǫ̀, including after-school and other extracurricular programs

closed all schools in yellowknife, dettah and ndilǫ̨ to in-class learning as well as after-school care programs; all extracurricular, club and sports activities for those under the age of 18 are also suspended
first known elementary, middle or high school opening in territory; date varied by school board with the majority returning to school august 31
all government employees transitioned to working from home. other employers encouraged to facilitate where possible.

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: announced that in-person classes will resume at all public and private schools in halifax regional municipality and sydney

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for all of n.s., closed all public and private schools

who: department of health and wellness, department of education and early childhood development
what: opened public schools for first day of classes

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: permitted licensed child care centres to open at 50% capacity, with a possibility to operate at full capacity if able to follow guidelines; opened family daycare homes at full operating capacity

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: regulated child care centres to close, to be reassessed after 2 weeks

announced that high school students who are currently attending online classes will move into a blended learning model; under this modified scenario 2 approach, high school classes will be split into 2 groups, and students will alternate between in-class instruction and online attendance, with access 5 days each week

who: department of health and community services
what: announced k–12 and post-secondary schools closed in st. john's metro region

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: opened public schools for the first day of classes across the province under scenario 1: k-12 students have near-normal in-person learning with health measures in place. memorial university and college of the north atlantic are providing primarily online learning.

who: department of health and community services
what: removed capacity limits on child care centres
closure of post-secondary education institutions; suspended classes

who: minister of education and early childhood development
what: regulated child care centres to close
opened public schools for the first day of in-person k-12 classes
child care centres can return to their regular licensed capacity, provided that measures can be taken to comply with guidelines; day camps can operate with a maximum of 50 children
closure of elementary, middle and high schools; suspension of classes
suspension of licensed child-care centres. this direction does not apply to home-based child care, as they care for a smaller number of children.
promoted review of business continuity plans and steps to ensure their employees can stay home when ill, without facing barriers such as the requirement for sick notes; and work from home if possible
opened public schools for the first day of in-person learning; student orientation held between september 10 and 11

who: government of british columbia, provincial health officer
what: closures of public elementary, middle and high schools. daycares remain open as an essential service.
all provincial restrictions around education (i.e., k–12 learning and post-secondary institutions) were lifted as a part of stage 3 in alberta's open for summer plan
announced the work-from-home order to be lifted, but still recommended, in step 2 of alberta's open for summer plan
for all communities with more than 50 cases per 100,000 people and with 30 or more active cases, announced all post-secondary learning to shift to online learning only
permitted k–12 schools to conduct school sport and performance activities off-site, provided they are related to educational activities, up to a maximum of 10 people, with distancing
mandated work-from-home order, unless employer requires physical operational effectiveness

mandated home learning for k–6 between january 4 and 11 and for grades 7 to 12 between november 20 and january 11 for the entire province of alberta; students who require in-person support that cannot be met through at-home learning are exempt; prohibited all levels of sport at collegiate and university level
announced that public schools would open for the first day of classes across the province. dates vary across school boards.
permitted day camps, including summer school, to resume in the cities of calgary and brooks; facilities may operate with a maximum cohort of 50 people, including staff and children

who: government of alberta, chief medical officer of health, premier
what: licensed child care, out-of-school care and preschool programs are closed.

who: government of alberta, chief medical officer of health, premier
what: closure of elementary, middle and high schools
mandated work-from-home order, unless employer requires physical operational effectiveness
opened schools for the 2021–2022 school year with the option of returning to in-person learning for the full school day or synchronous remote learning
